item.title: Top Libya rebel 'shot by Islamist militia'
item.description: Libyan rebel commander Abdel Fattah Younes was killed by an Islamist militia linked to his own side, a rebel minister says.

item.title: HMRC sorry for 'poor performance'
item.description: The chairman of HM Revenue & Customs apologises for its performance, saying it was "simply not good enough", after the service was attacked by MPs.

item.title: Met starts computer hacking probe
item.description: A new team of officers is to investigate claims of computer hacking, the Metropolitan Police has announced.

item.title: Royals gather for Zara's wedding
item.description: Senior royals are to gather in Scotland's capital city later to celebrate the marriage of Zara Phillips and Mike Tindall.

item.title: US Congress split over debt issue
item.description: The US Congress splits along party lines as it seeks a solution to an ongoing deadlock over raising the nation's debt limit and cutting the budget deficit.

item.title: Labour publishes media meetings
item.description: The Labour Party has published a list of the shadow cabinet's meetings with the media.

item.title: Egypt Islamists lead Cairo rally
item.description: Tens of thousands pack Cairo's Tahrir Square, after Islamists make their first call for nationwide demonstrations since President Mubarak's ousting.

item.title: Chavez in appeal to middle class
item.description: The left-wing Venezuelan President, Hugo Chavez, says he is willing to open up his political project to the middle classes and private sector.

item.title: Briton dies in Ibiza balcony fall
item.description: A young Briton has died in Ibiza after plunging from the balcony of a third

item.title: Teenagers accused of stab murder
item.description: Two teenagers are charged with the murder of a man found stabbed near a London Tube station.

item.title: Judge approves Watergate release
item.description: A US federal judge orders the release of former US President Richard Nixon's secret grand jury testimony in the Watergate scandal.

item.title: US police uproot 460,000 marijuana plants
item.description: Police in northern California tear up 460,000 plants and make more than 100 arrests in a major operation against illegal marijuana cultivation.

item.title: Search under way for jubilee wood
item.description: The Woodland Trust begins a search for a 500-acre site for a flagship woodland that will be planted to mark the Queen's Diamond Jubilee.

item.title: Arnie museum opens in his Austrian childhood home
item.description: Arnold Schwarzenegger's childhood home in Austria opens as a museum, on the day the Hollywood star and former California governor turns 64.

item.title: Live - England v India
item.description: England seek early wickets on day two of the second Test against India at Trent Bridge.

item.title: Sportsday Live - breaking news as it happens
item.description: The home nations await the World Cup draw, England look to fight back against India at Trent Bridge, plus more.

item.title: Live - Hungarian GP qualifying
item.description: Sebastian Vettel sets the fastest time in final practice for Sunday's Hungarian Grand Prix, with qualifying coming up at 1300 BST.

item.title: Home nations await World Cup draw
item.description: England, Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales await the draw for qualifying for the 2014 World Cup in Brazil.

item.title: Gill happy with Man Utd finances
item.description: Manchester United chief David Gill says he is "comfortable" with the club's finances in the wake of Friday's Parliamentary report into football governance.

item.title: Two injured as plane hits homes
item.description: Two men remain in hospital with serious burns after their plane crashed into two houses in Salford.

item.title: Bird skin burglar ordered to pay
item.description: A student who stole rare bird skins from the Natural History Museum at Tring is ordered to surrender the proceeds of his crime.

item.title: New bid in ambulance 'break' row
item.description: The Scottish Ambulance Service is expected to table a new proposal next week to resolve a dispute with its crews over breaks.

item.title: Glasgow Hogmanay party scrapped
item.description: Glasgow's traditional Hogmanay party in George Square is scrapped after the city council decides it is no longer value for money.

item.title: Houses evacuated in Downpatrick
item.description: A number of homes are evacuated in Downpatrick after a suspicious object was discovered on Saturday.

item.title: Major blaze at historic building
item.description: A listed building in County Tyrone is damaged in a fire in the early hours of Saturday morning.

item.title: League seeks Wrexham cash answers
item.description: The Football Conference is seeking urgent assurances that cash-strapped Wrexham will be able to complete its fixtures in the coming season.

item.title: One dies in Gwynedd road incident
item.description: One person dies in a road crash on the A493 at Pennal in Gwynedd.

item.title: Billionaire wins UK libel action
item.description: An Ethiopian-born billionaire has won £175,000 in libel damages over allegations he had hunted his daughter down so she could be stoned to death.

item.title: Bodies recovered from Congo ferry
item.description: At least 80 bodies are recovered from a river in the north-west of the Democratic Republic of Congo after a ferry collided with a cargo boat.

item.title: China mourns rail crash victims
item.description: Relatives of victims of a train crash which killed 40 people in China visit the scene of the accident and mourn their loved ones, amid widespread public anger.

item.title: Vietnam shoe plant fire kills 17
item.description: At least 17 people have been killed and 21 others injured in a fire at a shoe factory in northern Vietnam, police and media say.

item.title: Turkey's military chiefs resign
item.description: The chief of the Turkish armed forces, Isik Kosaner, resigns along with the heads of the army, navy and air force.

item.title: First funerals for Norway victims
item.description: The first funerals for victims of Norway's gun and bomb attacks are held, as the remaining names of the dead are released by police.

item.title: Air France crew 'lacked training'
item.description: The pilots of an Air France plane that plunged into the Atlantic in 2009 lacked adequate training to deal with high-altitude stalling, a report finds.

item.title: Honduras finds submarine cocaine
item.description: Naval forces from the US and Honduras recover 2.5 tonnes of cocaine from a semi-submersible craft intercepted off the Honduran coast.

item.title: Mass protests held across Syria
item.description: Tens of thousands of Syrians turn out for Friday protests against the rule of President Assad, while a blast damages an oil pipeline in the west.

item.title: UN tribunal names Hariri suspects
item.description: A UN-backed tribunal releases the names of four suspects - all linked to Hezbollah - indicted in the assassination of Lebanese ex-PM Rafik Hariri.

item.title: Pakistan attack 'kills 11 Shias'
item.description: Eleven people are shot dead in the Pakistani city of Quetta in an apparently sectarian attack in south-western Pakistan.

item.title: England v India as it happened
item.description: India reach stumps on day one of the second Test on 24-1 after bowling out England for 221 at an overcast Trent Bridge.

item.title: Klinsmann named as new US coach
item.description: Former Germany manager Jurgen Klinsmann is named as the new head coach of the United States national team following the sacking of Bob Bradley.

item.title: Fort Hood 'plot' soldier charged
item.description: An Awol US soldier accused of plotting an attack on a Texas military base shouts in court as he is charged with illegal possession of a firearm.

item.title: US growth much worse than thought
item.description: US economic growth is much weaker than first thought, figures from the Commerce Department show.

item.title: BSkyB gives £1bn to shareholders
item.description: BSkyB is returning £1bn to shareholders angered by the recent fall in the value of their shares amid the phone-hacking scandal.

item.title: Post may be left with neighbours
item.description: Royal Mail wants postmen and women to be able to leave undeliverable post with a neighbour if the addressee is not at home.

item.title: MP sorry for Morgan hacking slur
item.description: Conservative MP Louise Mensch apologises to former Daily Mirror editor Piers Morgan for accusing him of "boasting" about hacking phones.

item.title: Libya taunts UK over rebel death
item.description: The Libyan regime taunts the UK over the death of rebel military commander Gen Abdel Fattah Younes.

item.title: MPs vote against Murdoch recall
item.description: MPs vote against recalling News International's James Murdoch to give more evidence on phone hacking, but say he may be recalled later in the summer.

item.title: NHS trusts abuse system - Lansley
item.description: NHS managers are abusing the system by making patients wait longer for treatment, the health secretary says.

item.title: 'Super antibody' fights off flu
item.description: The first antibody which can fight all types of influenza A virus - which cause flu in humans - has been discovered, researchers claim.

item.title: Hospital student nurses withdrawn
item.description: About 100 student nurses are removed from a Lincolnshire hospital because of "serious concerns" expressed by the Nursing and Midwifery Council.

item.title: Fewer school children expelled
item.description: There has been another fall in the number of pupils excluded from schools in England in the past year.

item.title: Teachers' anger at pension cost
item.description: Teachers' unions have raised the prospect of further industrial action as they responded angrily to proposals for higher pension contributions.

item.title: More females in higher education
item.description: The number of young women at university or college in Scotland remains higher than the number of young men.

item.title: Apple holding more cash than USA
item.description: Apple now has more cash to spend than the United States government.

item.title: Whitehall's web habits revealed
item.description: Websites about belly dancing, Doctor Who and the Roman Empire are among those visited regularly by Department for Transport civil servants while at work.

item.title: Spotify sued over music streaming
item.description: Music streaming service Spotify is being sued in the US and Europe for allegedly violating patents held by PacketVideo.

item.title: Voices hard to hear for dyslexics
item.description: People with dyslexia have trouble recognising unfamiliar voices, a study finds - giving scientists new insight into human voice recognition.

item.title: Brain waves 'are the best brakes'
item.description: Scientists in Germany say tapping into drivers' brain signals to cut braking distances and avoid car crashes

item.title: Plant has a bat beckoning beacon
item.description: A rainforest vine has evolved dish-shaped leaves to attract the bats that pollinate it, scientists have found.

item.title: Plays help West End bounce back
item.description: London's theatreland recovers from a disappointing first quarter, with box office receipts for April to June up 2% on the same period last year.

item.title: Marvel wins hero copyright claim
item.description: Marvel wins a legal battle to retain copyright of its comic book characters including Spider-Man and The Incredible Hulk.

item.title: US film producer Polly Platt dies
item.description: Hollywood producer Polly Platt, who was nominated for an Oscar for art direction for Terms of Endearment, dies aged 72 in New York.

item.title: Naming places after famous people
item.description: This week the city fathers of Aberdeen, Washington, decided it might not be wise to name a bridge after Kurt Cobain. So what are the perils and pitfalls of renaming things after famous people?

item.title: Why do social networks want your real name?
item.description: Google+ is the latest social network to demand people's real names. But why do they need them?

item.title: The ice cream van cometh
item.description: Scene of the chime - why Johnny Vegas, Francis Rossi and Banksy are all ice cream van fans.

item.title: Pick of the week
item.description: A round up of the last week in Parliament - including phone hacking debates and some of the other key moments.

item.title: Test tube miracles
item.description: 25 years of IVF treatment at one of the UK's first dedicated centres

item.title: VIDEO: Afghan veterans' Ironman challenge
item.description: A team of armed forces veterans from Headley Court, all badly injured while serving in Afghanistan, are taking on the challenge of Ironman UK.

item.title: VIDEO: Honeymoon on hold for royal couple
item.description: The Queen's granddaughter, Zara Phillips, will marry her England rugby captain fiance, Mike Tindall, in Edinburgh this afternoon.

item.title: VIDEO: 'Worst yet to come' in Somalia
item.description: The food crisis in Somalia, threatening thousands of lives, is deepening with the United Nations warning that the worst is yet to come.

item.title: VIDEO: No end to deadlock over US debt
item.description: The US Senate has narrowly rejected a plan passed by the House of Representatives to raise the nation's debt limit.

item.title: VIDEO: Travel insurance to be made clearer
item.description: Travel insurance should become less fraught with the introduction of rules aimed at clearing up what consumers are covered for when they go away.

item.title: VIDEO: 50mph in a cardboard box on wheels
item.description: While motorsport is undeniably popular, the expense is just one reason most people will never even think of giving it a go - that's where the soapbox derby comes in.

item.title: VIDEO: Should you pay to park on Sundays?
item.description: Across the UK, the cost of car parking is rising, with some towns and cities charging fees to park seven days a week.

item.title: VIDEO: Mystery over Libyan rebel's death
item.description: Mystery surrounds the circumstances of the killing of Libya's rebel military commander, Gen Abdel Fattah Younes, a day after he and two aides were shot.

item.title: Crowded skies
item.description: Do we need a sixth London airport?

item.title: Distrusted rebel
item.description: John Simpson recalls meeting Libya's Gen Younes

item.title: VIDEO: 'People still miss me'
item.description: Arlene Phillips on Strictly, hip-hop and hard work

item.title: Free no more?
item.description: Westminster considers extension of parking charges

item.title: Le culture vulture
item.description: Is Sarkozy's new-found love of culture genuine?

item.title: Tomb raider
item.description: Exploring Egypt's Great Pyramid of Khufu in 3D
